qas.question: How is data stored on DVDs?

answers.text: digital blocks which make up each independent frame

qas.question: What device seperated the black and white and color signals in LaserDiscs?
Are comb filters exact, or is some data smudged?

answers.text: comb filters almost inevitably smudge some detail

qas.question: In what areas are comb filters most likely to lose detail?

context: LaserDisc was a composite video format: the luminance (black and white) and chrominance (color) information were transmitted in one signal, separated by <a1_0>the receiver<a1_0/>. While good comb filters can do so adequately, these two signals cannot be completely separated. On DVDs, data is stored in the form of <a0_0>digital blocks which make up each independent frame<a0_0/>. The signal produced is dependent on the equipment used to master the disc. Signals range from composite and split, to YUV and RGB. Depending upon which format is used, this can result in far higher fidelity, particularly at strong color borders or regions of high detail (especially if there is moderate movement in the picture) and <a3_0>low-contrast details like skin tones<a3_0/>, where <a2_0>comb filters almost inevitably smudge some detail<a2_0/>.
